Display taxa abundances as a stacked bar graph.

Source: R/stacked_plot.r
stacked_plot.Rd

Display taxa abundances as a stacked bar graph.

stacked_plot(
  biom,
  rank = NULL,
  taxa = 6,
  facet.by = NULL,
  facets = NULL,
  colors = NULL,
  patterns = FALSE,
  label.by = NULL,
  sort.by = NULL,
  dist = "euclidean",
  clust = "complete",
  other = TRUE,
  xlab.angle = 90,
  ...
)

Arguments

biom

A BIOM object, as returned from read.biom.

rank

What rank(s) of taxa to display, for example "Phylum" or "Genus". Run taxa.ranks() to see all options for a given BIOM object. The default, NULL, selects the lowest level.

taxa

Which taxa to give separate colors. An integer value will show the top n most abundant taxa. A value 0 <= n < 1 will show all taxa with that mean abundance or greater (e.g. 0.1). A character vector of taxon names will show only those taxa. Default: 6.

facet.by

Split into multiple plots based on this metadata column(s). Default: NULL.

facets

Optionally specify which facets to show and in what order. Default: NULL.

colors, patterns

A character vector of colors or patterns to use in the graph. A named character vector can be used to map taxon names to specific colors or patterns. Set to NULL or TRUE to automatically select. Set to FALSE to disable per-taxa colors or patterns. Default: colors=NULL, patterns=isFALSE(colors).

label.by, sort.by

What metadata column to use for labeling and/or sorting the samples across the x-axis. When sort.by=NULL, samples are arranged based on dist and clust, below. Default: label.by=NULL, sort.by=NULL.

dist, clust

Distance (dist) and clustering (hclust) methods to use for automatically arranging samples along the x-axis to group samples with similar composition near one another. Default: dist="euclidean", clust="complete".

other

Add an 'Other' taxa that ensures all bars sum to 100 Default: TRUE.

xlab.angle

How to rotate the tick labels on the x-axis. Options are 90 (the default) or 30.

...

Parameters for underlying functions. Prefixing parameter names with a layer name ensures that a particular parameter is passed to, and only to, that layer.

Value

A ggplot2 plot. The computed data points will be attached as attr(, 'data').

Examples

    library(rbiom)
    
    biom <- rarefy(hmp50)
    stacked_plot(biom, rank="Phylum")
